title: 113_hr4287
content: The "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act" may extend the patent term for using biological products. The "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act" allows for a 5-year extension of a patent for using biological products, provided certain conditions are met. To obtain an extension of a patent for a biological product, the owner must submit an application to the Director containing the identity of the product and patent, along with specific claim details. The extension cannot have expired before the application is submitted and must not have been previously extended under relevant sections of the law. To extend a patent for a biological product, the owner must provide the product and patent identity, as well as specific claim details. The patent must have been issued to an independent innovator or a qualified small business with ties to the innovator. To extend a patent for a biological product, the owner must provide product and patent identity, along with specific claim details. The patent should have been issued to an independent innovator or a qualified small business with ties to the innovator. Additionally, an application for commercial marketing of the biological product must have been filed under the Public Health Service Act, and a minimum of 10 years should have passed since the original submission for an exemption under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. To extend a patent for a biological product, the owner must provide product and patent identity, specific claim details, and a brief description of activities undertaken during the extension period. The Director determines patent extension eligibility based on application representations. If eligible, a 5-year extension certificate is issued. The Director may issue a certificate of extension for 5 years to the applicant, which becomes part of the original patent. If a patent's term would expire before a decision on extension is made, the Director can grant interim extensions of up to one year. The Director can extend the patent term for up to one year if eligible. Definitions include "biological product" and "Director." An "independent innovator" is defined as any individual. The term "independent innovator" refers to a person or entity who obtains a method of use patent for a biological product and is not affiliated with the holder of a marketing application approved for the commercial marketing of the product. The term "affiliated" in the context of the Public Health Service Act refers to any relationship of employment, control, or common ownership, whether direct or indirect. A "qualified small business" is defined as an entity with fewer than 500 employees, including employees of affiliates, and not affiliated with larger entities. A "qualified small business" is defined as an entity with fewer than 500 employees, not affiliated with the holder of the marketing application approved under section 351(a) of the Public Health Service Act. This section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to any unexpired patent issued before, on, or after that effective date.
